channel.title: Inla on Stats & bats
channel.description: Recent content in Inla on Stats & bats

item.title: Comparing inlabru with INLA
item.description: inlabru is an R package which builds on top of the INLA package. I had the opportunity to take a workshop on it during the International Statistical Ecology Workshop ISEC2018 in St Andrews. This was a five day workshop condensed into a single day, hence the pace was very high. It gave us a good overview of the possibilities of inlabru but no time to try it on our own data.

item.title: Temporal autocorrelation in INLA
item.description: One of the reason why I often use INLA is because it allows for correlated random effects. In this blog post, I will handle random effect with temporal autocorrelation. INLA has several options for this. There are two major types of model, the first handles discrete time step, the latter continuous time steps. Dummy data set This blog post was inspired by a post on the R-Sig-Mixed models mailing list.

item.title: Using a variable both as fixed and random effect
item.description: Categorical variable Discrete variable Intro Fit with lme4 Fit with INLA Continuous variable Conclusion One of the questions to answer when using mixed models is whether to use a variable as a fixed effect or as a random effect. Sometimes it makes sense to use a variable both as fixed and random effect. In this post I will try to make clear in which cases it can make sense and what are the benefits of doing so.
